channel.title: Best method of load distribution
channel.description:
I have 3 linux servers - two at one location, and one at the other. One is in pennsylvania and the other two are in manchester.
I want the site to be able to handle more users, while also being redundant (so if one fails, the site still works [albeit slower]).
The site will use PHP+MySQL, and will not be able to function without the database.
All the ideas I've had seem shit.. MySQL mirroring can cause nasty problems if they desync Remote SQL introduces a single point of failure, and is a bit slow..
I'd use round robin to select a server, because it's ok for what I need..
Any ideas?

item.title: Best method of load distribution
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“pkedpker, post:25, topic:372818”]My java server couldn’t handle more then 900 sockets opened at one time it would crash and I was using a very cheap dedicated server (20$ a month). this dedicated server which capped my sockets to 900 (meaning http traffic sockets+java server sockets).

So I’ve fixed that problem by coding a php script which detected how much sockets are in use ATM. By querying all servers which each server has a php script to tell how much sockets are used, so during page loading and it would echo a html frameset like this below with the server with the least amount of sockets used and route connection using frameset. Of course if a php script cannot be queried then the server has crashed or overloaded and you balance the load with the remaining servers simple as that.

<frameset cols="100%"> 
    <frame src="http://server1,2,3,4,5,etc.domain.com/"> 
</frameset>

it worked flawlessly for me as for expanding my business although I had no use for a database on my site.

But you can always have one server as a centralized master database, which all other servers connected to remotely (but IDK this could be slow due to network latency and a waste of bandwidth on cheap dedi servers, other then that you have very limited opportunities AFAIK).[/quote]

It seems like having one decent dedicated server for $100 that allows 65,000 some odd connections would be much better than hacking up a (pretty bad) solution with 5 cheap dedicated servers for $20 each (total $100), am I wrong?

item.title: Best method of load distribution
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

a very simple approach is round robin dns as you’ve stated with failover removal (although many would argue against this) and perhaps even geo-balancing…of course this causes problems with cookie sessions and those few isps that ignore ttl though. this also means that your dns should be fast and stable as fuck. you could also use a simple http load distributer and use a simple master-slave design; apache’s module is fairly decent.

better than a dns failover system would be a bgp approach, but it’s a pain in the ass to set up
